(Other roles: absta101 - Vigilante, Mirhawk - Innocent Child, everyone else - Vanilla Townies)

The Town won!

The Rules

1. Rules may be added, removed, or changed at my discretion.

2. If you do not post after 72 hours you will be prodded. You then have 48 hours to pick up the prod. If you do not pick it up after that time I will begin looking for a replacement. Weekends and holidays are counted as normal days.

3. a) The deadline for Day 1 will be 3 weeks, and all subsequent Days will have deadlines of 2 weeks. If a Day ends early, the remaining amount of time (rounded to days, not hours) will be added to the deadline of the next Day, up to a maximum of 1 week extra. I reserve the right to extend Day length, typically for the purpose of finding a desperately needed replacement.

b) Night rounds will last for 72 hours. During this time the thread will be locked, and all roles with night actions should send me a message telling me what they're going to do. Nights may be extended, just like Days.

4. Short version: Vote in the form Vote: example. As long as a vote isn't ambiguous, I'll count it. If it is ambiguous it won't ever count, even if clarified. You'll have to redo the vote. Also, unvoting is not necessary.

Long version: Voting must be made in the format Vote: example. The colon is optional, as is the space between the colon and the player's name. Capital letters are also optional. Unvoting is not necessary but appreciated. Votes using abbreviations for player names, misspellings of player names, and even misspellings of abbreviations of player names will all be accepted as long as they meet the above conditions. Abbreviations of misspellings of player names will be treated as mere abbreviations. In the event that a vote is ambiguous however, it will not be counted, not even retroactively. You can vote to not lynch anyone, and the rules for that are the same as regular voting. Trick votes aren't allowed.

5. No invisible or small text (defined as "text I have to copy and paste or quote to read").

6. To lynch in the Day rounds you need a simple majority of votes, or 50% rounded down +1.

7. Discussing this game anywhere outside of the game thread itself is forbidden, unless you are specifically told otherwise in your role PM. Discussing other ongoing games in this thread is also forbidden.

8. If you die you get one contentless "bah" post. Note that if you reach the required majority needed for a lynch then you are immediately dead (i.e., claiming that your death scene hadn't yet been posted so you were allowed to keep posting content won't work). During Twilight (after lynch majority is reached/after deadline hits, before round ending scene) anyone who is alive may post content (but the lynchee doesn't count as alive).

9. Lynch majority will not be reduced at deadline. If a lynch majority is not reached at deadline, No Lynch will occur.

10. Don't quote PMs you get from me. Paraphrasing is your friend.

11. If you are going to be gone for 72 or more hours, say so in the thread, or PM me. This will put your inactivity clock on hold. Do not count on me checking the V/LA thread.

12. Don't intentionally lie about out of game circumstances to gain an advantage in the game.

13. Flavor is flavor, no story clues or anything.

14. My color for this game will be blue, so don't use it.

15. In the event that you are modkilled you will automatically lose, regardless of who wins.

16. Do not lie to me about things related to the game.

17. Vote counts will hopefully be done close to the top of each page. If a full page goes by without a vote count then one will be edited in at the top of it.

18. If I make a mistake, tell me.

19. If you have a question about the rules, just ask.

20. Be considerate towards your fellow player. Excessive personal attacks will result in a warning, then forced replacement or modkill.

Note: If you're being insulted, say so in thread or PM me. I'm not you, so I have no idea if you don't care or if you're upset or whatever. Therefore, I will tend not to intervene.

21. If you think something you're about to do might break the rules, assume it will and message me asking if it's okay to do.

22. And of course all basic game mechanics of a standard Mafia game apply, such as roles and alignment being revealed on death etc...

Vanilla Townie PM:
You are a Vanilla Townie, and have nothing but your word and your vote. You win when all threats to the Town have been eliminated and at least 1 Pro-Town player is still alive.

The game thread is here. Please confirm by PMing me your role and alignment.


Mafia Win Condition:
You win when all non-Mafia players have been eliminated (or nothing can prevent this) and at least one Pro-Mafia player is still alive.

~Flavor~
To be added later if I feel like it.
Roles are going out. Please confirm via PM by messaging me your role and alignment.

Links:
The Review Thread - contains the discussion about this game's setup while it was still being reviewed. My introductory moderator notes from there are:
Moderator Notes:
Even though the Mafia have to choose who is making the kill, it does not actually matter.
Mafia are allowed to kill one of their own members if they so choose -- there may be some instances where killing the Vigilante Enabler themselves is a valid strategy.
Kills are indistinct from one another.

The purpose of this setup is to incorporate a vigilante into a setup without creating a setup where the Town can win even if they never lynch a single Mafia member. Although you could argue that in every setup with a Vigilante the Mafia can always just kill the Vigilante, that didn't seem good enough to me. Therefore, the Mafia have a slight boost in their power so that the odds of the Vigilante killing every single one of them (assuming perfect aim) is only 33% due to the chance of hitting the Vigilante Enabler.

It's my understanding that the Doctor only protecting against one kill is standard. On the other hand, it would be an extremely minor boost to town power if the Doctor could protect against all kills.

If this setup has a balance problem then I think it would be that it is biased towards the Mafia. Doctors are not especially powerful, and Vigilantes are swingy. I don't see an obvious solution, though. Reducing the Mafia size would be too much. Increasing the town size is not possible as it is already at 13 players. Adding another town PR would also probably be too much, when you take into account the presence of a Doctor. Anyway, this can be discussed with the reviewers.

In post 613, Rob13 wrote:P-edit: @Tierce - I don't understand that distinction. My thinking is that anything that has a town motivation has a scum motivation (i.e. to look like town), so I guess I don't see how you can extract the two. Care to explain that a bit more?
Go through the Mafia Discussion forums. Read articles by established players. Town and scum have different goals, and therefore will have different motivations. Yes, scum want to look Town, but they also need to push mislynches through sooner or later, or they need to bus their buddies convincingly. Town will push mislynches accidentally, but scum (at least outside of multiball) know when they are pushing a mislynch. You shouldn't go after someone because you think (or have proof) that their reads are wrong--but you should put yourself in their place and think if their reads make sense from a Town perspective.

This is one of the reasons that meta is so useful. Not to go "this player is playing differently from game A and he was Town there, therefore he must be scum here!", but to get inside the player's head and learn how they think. To understand what kind of reads they usually have as Town and as scum, how they rationalize events, how they act. You need to learn their playstyle, and know what is alignment-null instead of alignment-relevant--it varies from person to person. Empire and I are both very grounded on logic and meta; if we are pushing cases on gut alone, something is off--you'd need to figure out what and, most importantly, why it is off. That why is the motivation part.

Going through an ISO and dissecting it post by post to call out scummy behavior won't get you scum lynches, at least more often than random. Scum know how to behave like Town--after all, they have more information than you do. (Yes, they might slip, but Town will also unknowingly 'scum-slip' because they usually have no idea what they are doing.) When you say "I'm going to make a case on X", you're already going in with a preconceived notion that X is scum without combing for motivation.

In short, when you are trying to read someone's alignment, one of the best ways of doing it (in my opinion, obviously) is to gather information about that person and then go through their posts (never forget to check their play in context; ISOs are not enough because they strip away everything else that is happening around a person and that they may be willfully ignoring). Do their reads make sense from an uninformed Town point of view? Does their reasoning match their mindset? Do their reads and votes flow naturally at each point in the game, or are there awkward jumps that don't seem to match their expressed train of thought? Do they look like they are behaving in an opportunistic way that does not match their playstyle elsewhere? Are they arguing to figure out alignments, or are they just making noise for the sake of it?

No method is flawless, and some people will have scummy playstyles. For example: in my opinion, MagnaofIllusion and Thor665 are infamous for arguing pointlessly; a 'pointless argument' is defined here as 'an argument you don't drop even after you have reached a conclusion on that person's alignment'. This is why you should have a variety of questions you ask yourself when reading someone--those I listed on the previous paragraph should help you start; a little practice and knowledge of your fellow players goes a long way when learning to read alignments.

Read finished games without checking the alignments on the first post beforehand. Those are great for training. Yes, it's a lot of work, but no one said that being Town is a cakewalk.
